abstract.shortdesc: Concept short descriptions define the word or expression in the title. They answer the question What is?. They also often provide the Why? or What for?.

rule.rule-statement: When definitions apply to a specific context, start by stating that context.

examplefig.desc: The context In DITA specifies that this definition should be interpreted in the context of DITA. It is useful to specify it because technical audiences are used to a different definition for inheritance. Stating the context prevents confusion.
examplefig.codeblock: <concept><title>Inheritance</title> <shortdesc>In DITA, inheritance refers to the ability of XML elements to profit from transformations or css styles defined for the elements from from which they derive. Specializations define which elements derive from which.</shortdesc> ... <related-links> <link href="specialization.dita"></link> </related-links> </concept>

rule.rule-statement: Start definitions by stating the word or expression that they define.
rule.justification: It makes definitions self-contained, which makes them easier to reuse.

examplefig.codeblock:
<concept><title>Topics</title> <shortdesc>Topics are the smallest units of information that stand on their own. They are minimally composed of a title and a body.</shortdesc> ... </concept>
<concept><title>Topics</title> <shortdesc>Topics are the smallest units of information that stand on their own. They are minimally composed of a title and a body. Topics can be combined in multiple maps for reuse in many publications.</shortdesc> ... </concept>

<concept> <title>Modularity</title> <shortdesc>Modularity refers to the ability to separate and recombine information units for different publications, audiences or purposes.</shortdesc> ... </concept>
